show.title: Elf
show.headline: The best way to spread Christmas cheer

event.title: <show-title>Elf</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: With themed games, props, and singing loud for all to hear
event.description:
"Buddy the Elf, what's your favorite color?"

Don’t be a cotton-headed ninnymuggins this holiday season. Come out to Alamo Drafthouse and spread the cheer at this sugar-fueled, interactive holiday spectacular, packed with games, props, and, of course, singing loud for all to hear.

Bundle up for this celebration of one of the best holiday films ever made, period. Will Ferrell’s take on a North Pole elf trying to figure out Manhattan (“Watch out! The yellow ones don’t stop!”) just might be the funniest he’s ever been.

Our ELF Movie Party features all sorts of fun props, a gift "wrap off" before the film, and of course, your very own elf hat.

contentBlocks.paragraphs:
"Buddy the Elf, what's your favorite color?"

Don’t be a cotton-headed ninnymuggins this holiday season. Come out to Alamo Drafthouse and spread the cheer at this sugar-fueled, interactive holiday spectacular, packed with games, props, and, of course, singing loud for all to hear.

Bundle up for this celebration of one of the best holiday films ever made, period. Will Ferrell’s take on a North Pole elf trying to figure out Manhattan (“Watch out! The yellow ones don’t stop!”) just might be the funniest he’s ever been.

Our ELF Movie Party features all sorts of fun props, a gift "wrap off" before the film, and of course, your very own elf hat.

Don’t be a cotton-headed ninny-muggins. Add on our exclusive ELF pin set and collector’s glass, while supplies last, and celebrate the 20th anniversary of this modern classic. For a limited time, you can purchase a set of two enamel pins with art by our own Chris Bilheimer, and a 16 oz. collector’s glass (perfect for maple syrup), when you buy a ticket for a screening of ELF this holiday season. For shows in November, this offer is only available until 11:59PM on 10/30, and for December shows, you have until 11:59PM on 11/19, or until Santa runs out of supplies. Pick up your ELF pin set and glass at the box office before your showtime, and treat every day like Christmas.

show.title: Dazed and Confused
show.headline: We get older, but DAZED AND CONFUSED stays great

event.title: <show-title>Dazed and Confused</show-title> <event-type-title>w/ Cast Reunion</event-type-title>
event.headline: The iconic coming-of-age story + exclusive Q&A with cast members and director
event.description:
It’s been three decades since the release of writer/director Richard Linklater’s timeless DAZED AND CONFUSED, the film that – along with SXSW and Austin Film Society – helped place Alamo Drafthouse’s hometown on the (film industry) map.

That’s why we’re honored that stars Matthew McConaughey and Parker Posey will join Linklater and host Jack Black – prerecorded via Zoom – for a look back at a film that captured the look and the sounds of an entire generation.

DAZED & CONFUSED just might be the most endlessly watchable movie ever made. Houston filmmaker Linklater’s seminal 1993 coming-of-age film can be found on Quentin Tarantino’s 10 Best Films of All-Time list, and for good reason. Its freewheeling, lackadaisical humor is free of cliches, allowing Linklater to paint a genuine portrait of a time and place central to his life.

Set on the last day of school in 1976, DAZED AND CONFUSED is a rambling, hilarious, and honest look at small-town Texas teenagers and the cliques and keg parties that dominate their youth. With a talented young cast of future stars that includes Ben Affleck, Milla Jovovich, Renee Zellweger, Parker Posey, and Matthew McConaughey, DAZED & CONFUSED is perfectly nostalgic for freshmen and seniors alike.

show.title: National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation
show.headline: Nothing but the best for the Griswold Family Christmas

posterImages.altText: National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation movie poster

event.title: <show-title>National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Celebrate the season like an honorary Griswold
event.description:
No one knows how to do vacations like the Griswolds. Sure, their holidays are wild, chaotic, and often fraught with peril, but everyone’s family gatherings are a little stressful, aren’t they? Fortunately, you can just let Clark and the gang shoulder all that stress while you enjoy the ride at our CHRISTMAS VACATION Movie Party.

We’re giving it the full Movie Party treatment, with special props like pine tree air fresheners, yellow glow sticks, and ugly neckties to help you feel like you're an honorary Griswold. It’ll be more fun than a membership to the Jelly of the Month Club.

show.title: Batman Returns
show.headline: Christmas in Gotham isn't complete without a bat, a cat, and a penguin

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Michelle Pfeiffer as Catwoman in Batman Returns

portraitHeroImage.altText: Michelle Pfeiffer as Catwoman in Batman Returns

event.title: <show-title>Batman Returns</show-title>
event.headline: “Life’s a bitch, and now, so am I.”
event.description:
CATWOMAN! Sorry, didn’t mean to scream. It’s just that when I was a 7-year-old kid in 1992, that’s what I kept shouting after watching Tim Burton’s BATMAN RETURNS. When Oswald Cobblepott aka The Penguin (Danny DeVito) emerges from hiding beneath the streets of Gotham and begins wreaking a new brand of havoc, it’s up to Batman (Michael Keaton) to intervene and stop the ambitious criminal’s rise to power. But the odds are stacked against the caped crusader when The Penguin joins forces with corrupt businessman Max Shreck (Christopher Walken) and the unhinged feline femme fatale Catwoman (Michelle Pfeiffer).

Sure, yes, Batman is cool, and Penguin is scary, but Catwoman was serving pussy and power like no other. Were Selena Kyle and her alter ego Catwoman my queer awakening? I mean, probably. The skin-tight suit, the claws, the whip (knocking heads off mannequins and then jump roping out of a department store is gay rights), the big hair, the pathos! My goodness. I just couldn’t get enough of her, and when I strutted onto the playground back at school doing my best Catwoman, I realized that perhaps my experience was not universal. How could other kids not revel in the camp and chaos that I found so alluring? Well, because they were straight and boring. While ostensibly this is a Batman film, for me and many queers, it’s Catwoman’s world and we’re just living in it. Burton’s gothic wonderland reaches new heights in what would be his last foray into Gotham City. Gorgeous, dramatic, and deliciously queer, BATMAN RETURNS is one of the best Christmas movies there ever was, and we hope you’ll join us this holiday season and watch this classic on the big screen.

show.title: The Polar Express
show.headline: Journey beyond your imagination in this holiday family favorite

event.title: <show-title>The Polar Express</show-title> <event-type-title>Movie Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: An interactive holiday adventure the whole family will love
event.description:
Tickets, please. You can’t attend THE POLAR EXPRESS Movie Party without your ticket. And believe us when we tell you that the conductor (one of many Tom Hankses in this movie) is very particular about it.

Once you and the kiddos come aboard this special holiday Movie Party, we’ll have all sorts of fun surprises waiting for you, including kid-friendly props like a Santa hat, sleigh bells, and some fun activity sheets for you to take home. (And don’t worry, parents, we’ll be sure to lay down some ground rules so you’re not having to listen to jingle bells the whole time.)

With fun props, tasty treats, and more Tom Hankses than you can shake a candy cane at, THE POLAR EXPRESS Movie Party is a delightful, interactive holiday activity the whole family will love.

show.title: The Holiday
show.headline: A star-crossed winter romance that's cozier than a Crate & Barrel catalog

event.title: <show-title>The Holiday</show-title>
event.headline: A star-crossed winter romance that's cozier than a Crate & Barrel catalog
event.description: We could all use an escape every now and then. That’s certainly true for Amanda (Cameron Diaz) and Iris (Kate Winslet), two strangers who connect online and temporarily swap houses as a means of escaping from the stresses of their lives. And we’re inviting you to escape with us for a little bit with this special Champagne Cinema screening of Nancy Meyers’ utterly charming rom-com, THE HOLIDAY. With charismatic movie stars, enchanting settings, a heaping helping of humor and romance, and plenty of bubbly available to order, it’ll feel like a mini-vacation in the middle of your busy season.

event.title: <show-title>Trolls Band Together</show-title> <event-type-title>Family Party</event-type-title>
event.headline: Bring your family together for a rockin' party with your favorite trolls
event.description: We’re bringing Pop Village to Alamo Drafthouse for a toe-tapping TROLLS BAND TOGETHER Family Party! Never been to a Family Party? You’re in for a treat. Every Family Party features games, crafts, and fun props for you and your kids to enjoy before and after the movie. Your family will enjoy inflatable microphones, troll hair wigs, and can even craft their very own troll. Sing and dance along with all your favorite trolls, not to mention the first new song by NSYNC in over 20 years. Your ticket includes the movie, the activities, and the props. Be sure to arrive up to 30 minutes early to give yourself plenty of time to get in on the fun.

eventType.description: Our lobbies become your family’s place to celebrate film in wacky and immersive ways, with themed games, hands-on crafts, and activities before the show.

titleCardImage.altText: Family Party TT2

show.title: The Mist
show.headline: Fear changes everything

event.title: <show-title>The Mist</show-title> <event-type-title>in Black & White</event-type-title>
event.headline: Fear changes everything
event.description: In the aftermath of a storm, an eerie mist creeps into a small Maine town, besieging a group of shoppers inside a local grocery store. The mist is thick, hungry, and bursting with creepy crawlers from some sick, Lovecraftian dimension. An ideological rift emerges within the store between a cult of hyper-religious fanatics and those simply seeking survival. The question slowly becomes “Which hell is worse?” – the one in the store or the one outside? THE MIST is a wonderful blend of slimy creature-feature horror, paranoia, and commentary on the inherent terror of just being inside a grocery store. It’s also a total gem and one of the meanest Stephen King adaptations ever put to film. Featuring scenery-chomping performances by the likes of Tom Jane and Marcia Gay Harden – as well as acid-spiders, a giant squid, and spindle-legged beasties that would have made Salvador Dali scream with delight – THE MIST never shies away from being a nasty little piece of nightmare fuel. (Zane Gordon-Bouzard)

show.title: Dial Code Santa Claus
show.headline: Welcome to your new favorite holiday slayride

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Hero Image Dial Code Santa Claus

portraitHeroImage.altText: Hero Image Dial Code Santa Claus

event.title: <show-title>Dial Code Santa Claus</show-title>
event.headline: Your new favorite holiday slayride.
event.description:
Previously only available via VHS bootlegs, DIAL CODE SANTA CLAUS (aka DEADLY GAMES) is your new favorite holiday slayride. Thomas is a typical 1980s kid: he loves computers, role-playing games, and his dog. While Mom is away at the office on Christmas Eve, Thomas and his grandfather are left home alone—perfect timing for a disgruntled, bloodthirsty mall Santa Claus to climb down the chimney and terrorize the house. But Hell hath no fury like a mulleted ten-year-old with an arsenal of toys! Shot a year before HOME ALONE, the French-made DIAL CODE SANTA CLAUS has almost the same plot—only filled with more style, bloodshed, and Rambo references.

Screening a restored 35mm print.

Plus, you’ll get to hear the first new song by NSYNC in over 20 years (swoon)! Your ticket includes the movie, the activities, and the props. Our MC will get the dance party started at the listed showtime, but be sure to show up early to enjoy our custom pre-show.

show.title: Deep Red
show.headline: A yuletide symphony of blood from the master of giallo, Dario Argento

event.title: <show-title>Deep Red</show-title>
event.headline: Dario Argento's wintry slashterpiece in 4k.
event.description: Anticipating the eerie magic of SUSPIRIA, DEEP RED finds Dario Argento and creative partner Daria Nicolodi presenting a simple, Christmas-set slasher. At least, that’s what it appears to be. But within two minutes, it’s obvious that there’s nothing “simple” about DEEP RED at all. With this movie, Argento perfected the classy, ultra-violent sub-genre that would come to be known as giallo—and also perfected playing audiences like a fiddle. This includes Goblin’s soundtrack, which is a spook-a-delic prog-rock masterpiece that beautifully complements the movie’s dreamy mood

show.title: Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2
show.headline: The nightmare is about to begin...again!

event.title: <show-title>Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2</show-title>
event.headline: The nightmare is about to begin...again!
event.description:
Every day is "Garbage Day!" Ricky – the traumatized brother of the psychopathic Billy from SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT – has been released from the mental hospital. But before he can start life anew, Ricky must destroy Mother Superior, the powerful nun who caused his brother's violent demise. Be it by knife, umbrella, or car battery, Ricky unleashes a bloodbath of carnage on unsuspecting victims as he makes his way to Mother Superior's home on Christmas – Santa suit in tow. Making clever use of recycled footage from its predecessor and featuring an unhinged performance by star Eric Freeman, SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT PART 2 is an unforgettable yuletide horror experience.

DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive

eventType.title: Special Event
eventType.headline: For Movie Lovers, by Movie Lovers
eventType.description: Whether it’s a movie-inspired feast, an interactive party, or a screening paired with a live performance, we love sharing the movies we love in new and exciting ways.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Tales from the Hood
show.headline: Rusty Cundieff’s essential anthology

event.title: <show-title>Tales from the Hood</show-title>
event.headline: Rusty Cundieff’s essential anthology.
event.description:
There will never be another horror anthology as powerful as TALES FROM THE HOOD. Written and directed by Rusty Cundieff (FEAR OF A BLACK HAT) and executive produced by Spike Lee, this four-story anthology explores the terrors of racism, police brutality, and generational angst – all told from a Black perspective, and with help from acid-soaked effects by Screaming Mad George (A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET 3). Subversive, cathartic, and more relevant than ever, TALES FROM THE HOOD is essential ‘90s studio horror that paved the way for everything from GET OUT to Lovecraft Country.

Screening the 4K restoration

Content Warning: This film contains sequences of flashing lights, a brief scene featuring real-life crime photos, and scenes of domestic abuse.

eventType.title: Special Event
eventType.headline: For Movie Lovers, by Movie Lovers
eventType.description: Whether it’s a movie-inspired feast, an interactive party, or a screening paired with a live performance, we love sharing the movies we love in new and exciting ways.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: The Changeling (1980)
show.headline: George C. Scott is haunted by ghosts and grief

event.title: <show-title>The Changeling (1980)</show-title>
event.headline: George C. Scott is haunted by ghosts and grief
event.description:
In partnership with Severin Films, AGFA presents the fully-restored 1980 gem that made Martin Scorsese's 11 Scariest Horror Movies Of All Time list. This movie represents a career peak for both star George C. Scott and director Peter Medak (THE RULING CLASS.) Oscar-winner Scott delivers major feels as a classical music composer consumed by grief after his wife and daughter are killed in a shocking accident. When he moves to a secluded Victorian mansion, he finds himself haunted by a paranormal entity that unleashes an even more disturbing secret. Based on actual events!

Restoration via Severin Films; DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive

eventType.title: Special Event
eventType.headline: For Movie Lovers, by Movie Lovers
eventType.description: Whether it’s a movie-inspired feast, an interactive party, or a screening paired with a live performance, we love sharing the movies we love in new and exciting ways.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre Part 2
show.headline: An explosion of 1980s excess

landscapeHeroImage.altText: Texas chain saw massacre 1974 sp hero2

event.title: <show-title>The Texas Chainsaw Massacre Part 2</show-title>
event.headline: An explosion of 1980s excess
event.description:
Exploding with day-glo visuals and over-the-top gallows humor, THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE 2 is not what audiences expected from recovering wunderkind Tobe Hooper in 1986. But that’s exactly what makes it so special. Using the surreal terror of the first movie as a jumping off point, TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE 2 plays out like a deranged form of vaudeville with Leatherface as a sexually frustrated straight-man. Featuring electric performances from Bill “Chop Top” Moseley, Caroline Williams, and a chainsaw-wielding Dennis Hopper, it’s time to praise this movie for what it is—a drop-dead masterpiece of subversive 1980s horror.

Screening from an archival 35mm print.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Breathless (1983)
show.headline: He's the last man on earth any woman needs... and every woman wants.

event.title: <show-title>Breathless (1983)</show-title>
event.headline: Richard Gere bebops through LA in Jim McBride's essential remake.
event.description:
Jesse (a very hot Richard Gere) is obsessed with Jerry Lee Lewis, the Silver Surfer, and Monica (Valérie Kaprisky, equally hot), the French UCLA undergrad with whom he had a fling in Vegas. On his way to see her, Jesse shoots a cop at a traffic stop. Now, his mug is plastered all over town as a cop killer, which is really going to mess with his chances with Monica. After pioneering faux-documentary with DAVID HOLZMAN'S DIARY, cinematic heroes L.M. Kit Carson and Jim McBride reteamed to remake the opening salvo of the French New Wave, Jean Luc Godard's BREATHLESS. JLG's original film was a shocking provocation that, by 1983, had codified into a canonical classic. McBride and Carson's film is slippery, dangerously electric masterpiece the world still hasn't caught up with.

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Delicatessen
show.headline: Go in with a job, come out a sausage

event.title: <show-title>Delicatessen</show-title>
event.headline: Jean-Pierre Jeunet's breakthrough comic rampage in 4k.
event.description:
In a post-apocalyptic country where food is hard to come by and grain has the same lure as cash, an unemployed circus clown applies to work as a maintenance man in a dilapidated apartment building, not knowing the landlord is butchering his employees to feed his tenants! However, his charming demeanor causes a rift among the residents and threatens the whole meat-making operation, especially when he falls in love with the landlord’s daughter.

From the directing talents of Marc Caro and Jean-Pierre Jeunet and starring the wonderful, unique talents of Dominique Pinon (DIVA, AMELIE), DELICATESSEN is a wild original of cannibals, vegetarian troglodytes, and an imaginative setting that only the director of AMELIE and THE CITY OF LOST CHILDREN can provide. (Jazmyne Moreno)

4k DCP courtesy of Rialto Pictures.

eventType.title: Special Event

show.title: Eega
show.headline: A murdered man is reincarnated as a housefly and seeks to avenge his death

event.title: <show-title>Eega</show-title>
event.headline: Rated RRR for Reincarnation Revenge Rampage
event.description: Director SS Rajamouli is a visionary artist with a string of major blockbusters under his belt, including last year’s Academy Award-winning big-screen phenomenon RRR, but there’s nothing quite like EEGA. This is the film that introduced him to the world. Somewhere between DIE HARD, THE FAST AND THE FURIOUS, FINAL DESTINATION, and GHOST is EEGA. With the black-and-white morality of an old Western, Rajamouli shows us that love really does conquer all, for all creatures, great and small. (Josh Hurtado)

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Irma Vep (1996)
show.headline: French supercrime meets The Larry Sanders Show

event.title: <show-title>Irma Vep (1996)</show-title>
event.headline: French supercrime meets The Larry Sanders Show
event.description:
Olivier Assayas’s live-wire international breakthrough stars a magnetic Maggie Cheung as a version of herself: a Hong Kong action movie star who arrives in Paris to play the latex-clad lead in a remake of Louis Feuillade’s classic 1915 crime serial Les vampires. What she finds is a behind-the-scenes tangle of barely controlled chaos as egos clash, romantic attractions simmer, and an obsessive director (a cannily cast Jean-Pierre Léaud) drives himself to the brink to realize his vision. Blending blasts of silent cinema, martial arts flicks, and the music of Sonic Youth and Ali Farka Touré into a hallucinatory swirl of postmodern cool, Assayas composes a witty reflection on the '90s French film industry and the eternal tension between art and commercial entertainment. (Janus Films)

Presented in French with English subtitles

DCP courtesy of Janus Films

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: Mute Witness
show.headline: The most underrated wintry thriller of the 1990s

event.title: <show-title>Mute Witness</show-title>
event.headline: The most underrated wintry thriller of the 1990s
event.description:
The first international production shot in Moscow following the fall of the Soviet Union, MUTE WITNESS finds Billy, a non-verbal special effects artist, coming across an after-hours snuff film shoot. Marrying De Palma-esque maximalism with a cat-and-mouse thriller, fact and fiction collide in one of the most undersung genre works of the 1990s. Featuring a barely ambulatory Alec Guinness as a Russian gangster!

Get in on the ground floor of the cult before the end of the year. (Jake Isgar)

DCP courtesy of the American Genre Film Archive via Arrow Video

eventType.title: Special Event

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: The Blade
show.headline: Tsui Hark's phantasmagorical wuxia extravaganza.

event.title: <show-title>The Blade</show-title>
event.headline: Tsui Hark's phantasmagorical wuxia extravaganza.
event.description:
"A convulsive revenge saga that seems to me one of the best movies made anywhere in the 1990s. After it’s over, you’re not sure what hit you." - David Bordwell, historian/critic

Missing out on seeing The Blade on the big screen would be like going to the carnival and not going on the gnarliest, biggest and wildest ride. A masterpiece by anyone’s standards, The Blade is Tsui Hark’s tribute to the martial arts films he grew up with. It’s a reimagining of director Chang Cheh’s landmark wuxia (swordplay) classic, The One-Armed Swordsman (1967), as a psychotronic phantasmagoria full of scars and tattoos, mutilation, amputation, sexual frustration, and sharp, heavy chunks of steel splitting muscle and breaking bones. Rapid cutting, berserker camera movement, frenetic choreography and compositions packed to bursting with rhythm, texture and detail, Tsui Hark's revved-up ancient China roars away from the viewer like an out-of-control freight train, never saying what can be shown, never showing what can be said. Brains and eyeballs are battered and bruised and the audience has to run to keep up, but the experience of seeing one of the world's best directors at the top of his game is indescribably ecstatic. (Subway Cinema)

35mm print courtesy of Park Circus.

Presented in Cantonese with English subtitles.

titleCardImage.altText: Special Event Event Type Title Card

show.title: The Dragon Lives Again
show.headline: Not even death can stop Bruce Lee!

posterImages.altText: THE DRAGON LIVES AGAIN sp poster

event.title: <show-title>The Dragon Lives Again</show-title>
event.headline: Not even death can stop Bruce Lee!
event.description: Bruce Lee is dead! Long live Bruce Lee! Not even slightly inconvenienced by the lack of an actual living Bruce Lee, opportunistic producers unleashed a tidal wave of Brucesploitation movies starring martial artists with names like Bruce Li, Bruce Le, and Bruce Leong. As the trend reached peak saturation, the gimmicks got weirder: Bruce Lee vs. Supermen, Bruce Lee vs. the Clones of Bruce Lee, Bruce Lee vs. Gay Power! None of them are as weird, however, as THE DRAGON LIVES AGAIN, which begins where Bruce's life ended. The now-dead Lee finds himself in the underworld, where after incurring the wrath of the King of the Underworld, he meets Popeye the Sailor Man at a bar. Sound weird yet? A coalition of criminals led by "The Exorcist" and including such illustrious members as James Bond, Clint Eastwood, "The Godfather," Emmannuelle, and Dracula begin plotting against the King and attempting to kill Bruce. This is zany, out-of-control genre filmmaking at its best. Expect wacky slapstick, weird sex jokes, and genuine kung fu fighting set to music stolen from other soundtracks.

show.title: To Die For
show.headline: Kidman shines in tabloid trash turned high art

event.title: <show-title>To Die For</show-title>
event.headline: Kidman shines in tabloid trash turned high art
event.description: Gus Van Sant turns tabloid trash to quick-witted high art in this ripped-from-the-headlines tale of a TV reporter (Nicole Kidman) and the two boneheaded teens (baby-faced Casey Affleck and Joaquin Phoenix) she hires to kill her husband. One of the seminal Nicole Kidman performances, TO DIE FOR cemented her status as one of the rising stars of her era and set the stage for a long-spanning career full of fearless transformations.

Volunteer as tribute for our exclusive Panem Party screening of THE HUNGER GAMES: THE BALLAD OF SONGBIRDS AND SNAKES and our party mentors will lavish you with themed props, photo ops, and interactive fun. show.title: Planes, Trains & Automobiles
show.headline: Traveling on Thanksgiving was always a nightmare – just ask Martin and Candy

show.title: Wild Things
show.headline: An erotic thriller with more twists than a pretzel!

event.title: <show-title>Wild Things</show-title>
event.headline: “Lurid trash…I liked it.” – Roger Ebert
event.description:
Is Wild Things queer-baiting sexploitation garbage or an excellent '90s neo-noir class commentary? We say it’s both. What good is such a dubious binary when discussing a film that is this much fun? The upscale Miami suburb of Blue Bay is shocked when smarmy school guidance counselor Sam Lombardo (Matt Dillion) is accused of rape by two students. Wealthy it-girl Kelly Van Ryan (Denise Richards) and working-class student Suzie Toller (Neve Campbell) seem to be telling the truth, but hardnosed police detective Ray Duquette (Kevin Bacon) and his partner Detective Gloria Perez (Daphne Ruben-Vega) aren’t so sure. Twists, twirls, and turns ensue as this all-star cast navigates the sticky swamp of class, revenge, desire, and murder in director John McNaughton’s (HENRY: PORTRAIT OF A SERIAL KILLER) Shakespearean love letter to noir cinema. This naughty piece of “trash” will keep you guessing through the closing credits. (Micheal Foulk)

DCP courtesy of Sony Pictures Repertory

heroImage.altText: Hlk crazy rich asians black tie 13 1

titleCardImage.altText: Advance Sreening Web HERO 1920x1080

show.title: Saw X
show.headline: Explore the untold chapter of Jigsaw's most personal game

show.title: The Wedding Singer
show.headline: Party with Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore like it's 1985

show.title: Scream (1996)
show.headline: "Do you like scary movies?"

event.title: <show-title>Scream (1996)</show-title>
event.headline: “Do you like scary movies?”
event.description: In 1996, the once innocuous question became synonymous with terror with the release of Wes Craven’s SCREAM. Based on an original script penned by struggling *homosexual* screenwriter Kevin Williamson simply titled “Scary Movie,” SCREAM became a surprise hit earning $173 million worldwide, a record for slasher films. SCREAM’s concept was deceptively simple: beautiful teenagers in a small northern California town receive menacing phone calls from a stranger before being killed by a man in a ghostly mask. Williamson’s script complicated the concept by including references to the classic slasher films of the '70s and '80s and self-aware characters who were well-versed in the plot points and cliches of the horror film genre. The meta-slasher film was born. AND IT’S SUPER QUEER. Featuring dialogue that only a gay person would write, SCREAM is quotable out the wazoo and it’s so damn sassy. “She has her own bubble butt boyfriend, Billy,” is a line in this film, folks. And don’t get us started about the sexual tension between Billy Loomis (Skeet Ulrich) and Stu Macher (Matthew Lillard) – those are two men who have had sex together, damnit. Sidney (Neve Campbell), Tatum (Rose McGowen), and GALE FUCKING WEATHERS (Courtney Cox) have all become queer feminist icons and for good reason – they exude power and poise in a way few horror film heroines are afforded the opportunity to. And Sweet Deputy Dewey (David Arquette), the bumbling himbo of our dreams, how could you not fall deep in gay love with such an earnest and goofy character? SCREAM is a perfect film and one of the queerest slasher films ever, and its legacy includes five very queer sequels and more to come. Don’t miss your chance to catch this horror classic on the big screen. Don’t fuck with the original, y’all.

marketStrings.value: The personal closed captioning device displays feature film dialogue and other audio in the form of English-language text for individuals who are deaf or hard of hearing.

The descriptive audio headset provides individuals who are blind or have low vision with an English-language narration of the details of the feature presentation that can't be understood by the soundtrack alone.

Upon request at the box office, we provide assistive listening headsets with amplified audio for those individuals who are hard of hearing. For guests who prefer to use their own hearing aids, neck loops, or cochlear implants, our assistive listening headsets have a 3.5mm headphone jack to connect to those devices.

In order to ensure the highest quality experience for all guests, you may not enter a movie after it has started. We’d love to see you up to 30 minutes early. Running late? No worries, we will happily exchange your ticket for a different showtime or a raincheck to a future show.

sessionAttributes.name: All Ages
sessionAttributes.description: For all ages shows, we welcome babies and kids of all ages. The no talking rules are relaxed, since kids will be kids. But other than that, you can expect the full Alamo experience.

sessionAttributes.name: Kid Friendly
sessionAttributes.description: Grab the fam and let the fun begin! Our Kid Friendly screenings include pre-show activity sheets and crayons, a relaxed noise policy, and kids menus. Ages 3+ welcome with a parent or guardian.

formats.title: 2D Digital
formats.headline: Digital format projected using a digital projector.
formats.description: Digital format projected using a digital projector.

formats.title: 3D Digital
formats.headline: All the digitalness of the Digital 2D format, but with an extra dimension!
formats.description: All the digitalness of the Digital 2D format, but with an extra dimension!

formats.title: 35mm
formats.headline: Film print projected using film projectors.
formats.description: The industry standard for theatrical film releases prior to digital cinema. Film print projected using film projectors.

agePolicies.name: !!DO NOT USE!! All Ages
agePolicies.description: All ages will be allowed at all screenings of this show.

agePolicies.name: Rated G
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.name: Rated PG
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.name: Rated PG-13 (Standard)
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.name: Rated PG with Adult Focus
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 18 must be accompanied by an adult. Children ages 6+ admitted. Children 5 and under (including infants) are ONLY admitted during specifically designated "All Ages" and "Family Friendly" screenings.

agePolicies.name: Under 13
agePolicies.description: All minors under the age of 13 must be accompanied by an adult.
